title: Elaine Castle
text:
Elaine Castle is a 7,431-foot-elevation (2,265 meter) summit located in the <a href="Grand%20Canyon">Grand Canyon</a>, in <a href="Coconino%20County%2C%20Arizona">Coconino County</a> of northern <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, <a href="Southwestern%20United%20States">US</a>. It is situated three miles north-northwest of <a href="King%20Arthur%20Castle">King Arthur Castle</a> near the head of Shinumo Creek, and immediately southwest of Lancelot Point. <a href="Topographic%20relief">Topographic relief</a> is significant as it rises 2,800 feet (850 meters) above Merlin Abyss in one mile. According to the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> system, Elaine Castle is located in a <a href="cold%20semi-arid%20climate">cold semi-arid climate</a> zone.
History.
<a href="Clarence%20Dutton">Clarence Dutton</a> started the tradition of naming geographical features in the Grand Canyon after mythological deities and heroic figures. Elaine Castle was named by <a href="cartography">cartographer</a> <a href="Evans%20Butte">Richard Tranter Evans</a> (1881–1966), after <a href="Elaine%20of%20Astolat">Elaine of Astolat</a>, from the <a href="Legend%20of%20King%20Arthur">Legend of King Arthur</a>, in keeping with an <a href="Arthurian%20legend">Arthurian naming theme</a> for other geographical features in the vicinity, e.g. "King Arthur Castle", "<a href="Guinevere%20Castle">Guinevere Castle</a>", "Excalibur", "Gawain Abyss", "<a href="Holy%20Grail%20Temple">Holy Grail Temple</a>", "Bedivere Point", "Lancelot Point", and "Galahad Point". This feature's name was officially adopted in 1908 by the <a href="U.S.%20Board%20on%20Geographic%20Names">U.S. Board on Geographic Names</a>. Donald Davis climbed Elaine Castle on June 27, 1969, placing the first cairn on Elaine, but was not the first person there as he found evidence that <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a> had been there. <a href="Harvey%20Butchart">Harvey Butchart</a> climbed it on August 9, 1969, finding the cairn that Davis had built.
Geology.
This <a href="butte">butte</a> is composed of a <a href="Permian">Permian</a> <a href="Toroweap%20Formation">Toroweap Formation</a> <a href="caprock">caprock</a> on cream-colored Permian <a href="Coconino%20Sandstone">Coconino Sandstone</a>. This sandstone, which is the third-youngest stratum in the Grand Canyon, was deposited 265 million years ago as sand dunes. Below the Coconino Sandstone is reddish slope-forming, Permian <a href="Hermit%20Formation">Hermit Formation</a>, which in turn overlays the <a href="Pennsylvanian%20%28geology%29">Pennsylvanian</a>-Permian <a href="Supai%20Group">Supai Group</a>. Further down are strata of the cliff-forming <a href="Mississippian%20%28geology%29">Mississippian</a> <a href="Redwall%20Limestone">Redwall Limestone</a>, and slope-forming <a href="Cambrian">Cambrian</a> <a href="Tonto%20Group">Tonto Group</a>. Elaine Castle owes its isolation to <a href="Fracture%20%28geology%29">lines of fracture</a>. Precipitation <a href="Surface%20runoff">runoff</a> from Elaine Castle drains south to the <a href="Colorado%20River">Colorado River</a> via Shinumo Creek.
